description.narrative: Projektet syftar till att stödja OHCHR's kontor i Tunis i dess arbete med att bekämpa straffrihet, stärkt redovisningsansvar, rättssäkerhet och ett demokratiskt samhälle. OHCHR arbetar också med ekonomiska, sociala och kulturella rättigheter och att bekämpa fattigdom samt för en förbättrad efterlevnad av FN's MR-mekanismer.

The project aims to support the work of OHCHR office in Tunis in its work to combat impunity and strenghten accountability, the rule of law and democratic societies. The office also pursues economic, social and cultural rights and combats inequalities and poverty as well as increased compliance with the UN human rights mechanisms and bodies.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The OHCHR Tunisia office managed to achieve most of the results and objectives it had set out to do. Within the "rule of law" objective of the program, big steps where taken on transitional justice. The OHCHR provided technical assistance and trainings and contributed to the establishment of the Truth and Dignity Commission (TDC) and its delivering on its mandate; with for example 62,000 complaints investigated and 3000 victims having been consulted in the elaboration of a reparation program. In the area of "development" a key result was the finalization of a guide on economic, social and cultural rights for judges, lawyers and civil society. This guide was developed in cooperation with another of Sida's supported partners, ILAC. In the upcoming period OHCHR plans to slowly shift focus to working on economic, social and cultural rights (together with combating inequality) while also continue to consolidate the gains in public freedoms, rule of law and the national protection system framework. Within the "widening democratic space" the OHCHR has contributed to the establishment of mechanisms for the monitoring of respect of freedom of opinion and expression with the Monitoring Unit on the Safety of Journalists of the National Syndicate of Tunisian Journalists now being fully operational. It receives and investigates complaints of attacks against journalists and provides legal advice on access to remedies. Within "non-discrimination", four years of advocacy, consultations with civil society, technical advice to the drafting committee and parliament, contributed to the successful adoption of the Law on Violence against Women in July 2017. Within "human rights mechanisms" a key result was the establishment of the National Mechanism for Reporting and Follow-up, an inter-ministerial committee in charge of reporting and follow-up in relation to international and regional human rights mechanisms. The working methods were established largely in line with international standards and best practices. The OHCHR provided initial advocacy on the importance of establishing the mechanism and then later also provided technical support in the designing and establishment of it as well as in its work.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
